explosives.rationale: Containing no atom groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" (m-cresol) or "solid" (o- and p-cresol), according to GHS definition

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" (m-cresol) or "solid" (o- and p-cresol), according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "liquid" (m-cresol) or "solid" (o- and p-cresol), according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: The flashing point is 86degC (ICSC 1999) for m-cresol (Category 4); classified into Category 6.1 and Class 8 (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods, UN#2076 and 3455). Classified as "solid" (o- and p-cresol), according to GHS definition

flammable_solids.classification: Not applicable (m-cresol) Not classified (o- and p-cresol)
flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" (m-cresol), according to GHS criteria. Classified into Division 6.1 and Class 8 (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods, UN#2076 and 3455) (o- and p-cresol).

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no atom groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

pyrophoric_liquids.classification: Not classified (m-cresol) Not applicable (o- and p-cresol)
pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Not pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures: the flashing point is 626degC for m-cresol (ICSC,1999). Classified as "solid"(o- and p-cresol), according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_solids.classification: Not applicable (m-cresol) Not classified (o- and p-cresol)
pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid"(m-cresol), according to GHS definition. Not pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures: the flashing points are 599degC for o-cresol (ICSC, 2000) and 559degCfor p-cresol (ICSC, 2000).

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available; the melting points are 30degC for o-cresol (ICSC, 2000), 11-12degC for m-cresol (ICSC, 1999) and 35degCfor p-cresol (ICSC, 2000) (test temperature: 140degC).

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing oxygen (but not fluorine and chlorine), with the oxygen bound to carbon and hydrogen (but not to other elements) (m-cresol). Classified as "solid" (o- and p-cresol), according to GHS criteria.

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" (m-cresol), according to GHS criteria. Organic compounds containing oxygen (but not fluorine and chlorine), with the oxygen bound to carbon and hydrogen (but not to other elements) (o- and p-cresol).

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: No data available. Corrosivity to metals remains uncertain, though classified as "corrosive substances" (as the classification based on UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods includes "skin corrosivity") (UN#2076 and 3455).

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the testing data of rat LD50 (oral route) of 1,454 mg/kg (IUCLID, 2000).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the testing data of rabbit LD50 (dermal route) of 2,000 mg/kg (EHC 168, 1995).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" (o- and p-cresol) or "liquid" (m-cresol) according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the evidence of "irreversible destruction of skin tissues" (EHC 168, 1995) from the rabbit skin irritation test, although the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the evidence of "corneal opacity and arterialization" from the rabbit eye irritation test (CERI Hazard Data 97-9-1, 1998).

respiratory_skin_sensitizer.classification: Respiratory sensitizer: Classification not possible Skin sensitizer: Classification not possible
respiratory_skin_sensitizer.rationale: Respiratory sensitizer: No data available Skin sensitizer: No data available

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the technical guideline (Appendix 1). CAS1319-77-3 does not define the isomeric composition (o, p or m) or the positions of the methyl and hydroxyl groups in cresol, and there is no data on the in vivo mutagenicity of isomeric mixtures. However, cresol (mixture) is considered to have no in vivo mutagenicity in general, based on the evidence from EHC 168 (1995) and NTP TOX9 (1992) that 60:40 m/p-cresol was negative for somatic cell mutagenicity in vivo (demonstrated in mouse micronucleus test using red blood cells), o-cresol was negative in mouse micronucleus test using red blood cells and in mouse dominant lethal test and m-cresol was negative in mouse bone marrow chromosome aberration test.

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that each of the cresol isomers (o-, m- and p-cresol) is placed in Category C by EPA (1991), although cresol (CAS No. 1319-77-3) itself is not placed in any category for carcinogenicity.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.classification: Category 1 (blood system, respiratory organs, heart, liver, kidneys, central nervous system) Category 3 (narcotic effects)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "deep coma, severe methemoglobinemia, formation of Heinz bodies, intravascular hemolysis, clot formation, liver fatty degeneration, kidney fatty degeneration, tubulonecrosis" (CERI Hazard Data, 97-9, 1998) and "myocardial dysfunction, hemorrhagic pulmonary edema, necrosis of hepatic lobules, necrosis of kidneys, brain congestion, brain swelling (EHC 168, 1995) and evidence from animal studies including "clonic spasm, bloody urine, airway irritation, necrosis of the lung and liver" (DFGOT Vol. 14, 2000). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value range for Category 1.The basis of the classification includes data on cresol with unknown composition or containing other substances.

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification: Category 1 (cardiovascular system, blood system, kidneys, central nervous system) Category 2 (respiratory organs)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "circulatory disorder, minor decreases in red-cell, white-cell and platelet counts" (MOE Risk Assessment Vol. 2, 2003) and "headache, nausea, vomiting, hypertension, renal impairment, abnormal blood levels of calcium, significant tremor" (DFGOT Vol. 14, 2000) and the evidence from animal studies including "hyperplasia of nasal respiratory epithelium" (CERI Hazard Data 97-9-2, 1998 and 97-9-3, 1998). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value range for Category 2. The basis of the classification includes data on cresol with unknown composition or containing other substances and mixtures of m- and p-cresol.

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 2 from 48 hours EC50=7mg/L of the crustacea (Amphipod) (CERI/NITE Hazard Assessment Report (preliminary version), 2006).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since there was rapidly degrading (the decomposition (ortho, meta and para isomer): >60% (SIDS (1998, 2005)) and the bio-accumulation was low (log Kow=1.95 (PHYSPROP Database (2005))), it was classified into Not classified.
